1.84.text: Too often, affairs are seen as the outcome of random horniness

8.18.text: but that's very rarely the case.

10.34.text: When it comes to affairs, we spend far too long being incensed or secretive

15.36.text: and far too little time trying to understand.

18.40.text: In truth, affairs stem from a very fiddly aspect of our romantic psychology.

23.60.text: In relationships with a partner, all of us need carefully calibrated mixtures of two different ingredients.

30.96.text: We have a need for closeness

37.68.text: to feel we can hug, touch, be cosy, intimate and entirely relaxed and at home with someone.

43.60.text: We want them to know our thoughts and to wander freely in their minds too.

48.24.text: But we also need distance enough

51.04.text: not to feel cloyingly submerged, subsumed or owned by another.

55.20.text: We want to retain a sense of freedom,

57.76.text: we need a private room to which we alone have the key.

61.90.text: Any imbalances towards over-closeness or over-distance

65.96.text: may prove catastrophic if left unaddressed.

69.00.text: In a relationship which threatens to lean perilously towards over-closeness

74.44.text: we can be driven to strain a powerful urge to prove to ourselves

78.60.text: that not everything we do and are is owned by the partner,

82.40.text: that we remain desirable to the world and a going concern in and of ourselves.

87.60.text: Going to bed with a new person might not simply be about lust,

91.40.text: it's about escaping the alarming feeling that one's whole identity

95.48.text: appears to be on the verge of dissolving into the couple.

100.60.text: But too much distance can undermine fidelity no less powerfully.

105.04.text: The distance reads like constant rejection:

107.60.text: when we try to touch the partner, they move away or sigh.

111.20.text: When we bring up something personal,

114.68.text: We may end up having an affair

116.60.text: not because we don't love the partner anymore,

121.00.text: And yet the distance they appear to be imposing on us,

128.80.text: It's the final irony, but if caught would be accused of not caring,

133.44.text: when it was caring too much that might have inspired the whole mistaken escapade.

138.40.text: Tragically, two people almost never enter a relationship with the same needs for distance or closeness,

145.00.text: that's why in every couple we hear the accusation that one person is too clingy

154.40.text: for what are, at heart, just two different ways of feeling comfortable in love.

159.28.text: It's therefore an early imperative in any relationship

162.80.text: to work out what the relative needs for distance and closeness actually are

169.20.text: not to get angry about it,

170.80.text: and mutually and with good humour to apologise for ones distinctive contribution to it.

176.10.text: Only thus can we hope to ensure that the gap won't lead in an online chat, at a bar or at a conference

183.10.text: to a situation where only an affair feels like a plausible solution to the vexing problems of distance and closeness.
